content: Like the idea of the clash, but there should be at least one test case in the IDE that exceeds 100 jumps. The mention of a maximum of 100 jumps at the end can easily be missed.

There are several problems with this clash. As other have mentioned:

1. The tests and validators don't match. Leading to clashers getting 100% on tests then 83% on validators.

2. The description is incorrect and misleading. It says "[the] frog jumps following the order [...] [jump1, jump2, ...]" when it actually jumps according to the integer listed at the position of the array where it is before jumping.

3. The validator that leads to 83% is "Long Array jump stay in after 100 jumps with little jumps" which is the only one that makes use of the 100 jump rule. It is also coded with an incorrect answer, since the frog ends up outside of the array on the 100th jump, landing at position 100, in an array from 0..99. So the answer should be 100, not -1.

Downvoted, for reasons highlighted by @BanjoMan and @AlexTelon
If you make the changes, I'll upvote again, the clash idea is nice :)

Downvoted:
Not a single one of the test cases is similar to its validator.
I had 100% on all tests.
I submitted and got 83%, and I won the clash, being the highest.

This is not how tests and validators work. Each validator should work similarly to its test but not be identical. The idea is to prevent people from just figuring out the answers to the tests and submitting code that spits out those answers. BUT the tests should allow someone to debug their solution so that it passes the validators.
The test cases are not equivalent to validators ‚Äì notably there's no visible test for staying in the array for 100 jumps.
This contribution hasn‚Äôt received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

The task is to use the current position as an index into the given list of numbers. And by that way figure out how far to jump each time. Like a program counter.

But this statement seems to state that we should use the jumps in the order that they were given:

The frog jumps following the order of the integers in the array, i.e. [jump1, jump2, jump3 ... , jumpN].

The two examples provided also do not highlight the fact that the position should be used as an index to get the next jump distance. They work just as well by always using the next jump in line. 

In the first example we take the first 3 jumps in order. In the second example the two last numbers (jumps) are the same.

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool idea. I think I would have been a bit nasty and removed the 100 jumps limit to force people to check for repetitive patterns. You are soft ! :p 
I'm kidding, it's great

It's not very clear which array the frog is jumping out of.

I assume it is inside of, and jumping out of the input array that is passed into the solution code?

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Perfect

I think you miss a '-1' in your test called 'Long Array jump out with little jumps', there is only '1' into, so the frog will go out (my solution says 99)
Otherwise, all is good for me, I will approve when this is changed ;) 
Very nice !

‚úÖ Approved the contribution.
Comment: +1

Goal section
* You write "Return the position of the frog". How is position defined?
* Is the frog's starting position defined as 0? If so, state it.
* Can a frog jump to the left of 0? If not, state it.
* A frog can only jump left and right? If so, state it.
* "positiv" should be spelled as "positive".
* "to direction" should be "the direction".
* "Frog" can be deleted in "Frog [jump1, jump2...".
* What do you mean by "one indice" and "three indices"? Is it clearer / correct to say "one unit" and "three units" instead?
* I don't understand your example of [1, 1, 3, -1, 1]. Does it mean the frog's positions are:
> 0 + 1 = 1
> 1 + 1 = 2
> 2 + 3 = 5
> 5 - 1 = 4
> 4 + 1 = 5???
* What is the meaning of "jump out"? The statement does not seem to explain where the "exit" is.
* As a result, I don't understand why the answer is -1 for the last validator.

Output section
* What is the meaning of "Integer of the jumps"?
* What is the meaning of "stays in array"?
Thanks for the detailed review. I have updated the information. Does it describe it better?
Hi Maurice, thanks for checking that. Have you also seen the max of 100 jumps? I have adjusted the test case label to make it more clear. Could you please have a look again? Thank you =)
Thanks for your hint. I have make it more clear in the statement. If it isn‚Äôt enough could you give me an example?

I agree with you. Had the exact same problem here.
Downvoted the clash for the same reason.

Oh yes, my bad, i forget this point.
Thank's for the fast answer

I have edited the statement to make it clearer, though I am worried that it may have become too long...

Also I still don't answer the difference between the last test and the last validator. In your code you have included 100 as the upper limit of the index of the array, but it is nowhere mentioned in the statement. Why 100? If it is outside the array, then it is outside the array, no matter the index is greater than 100 or not, isn't it?

Damn, your description sound so amazing better =) I definitely need to improve my English ^^Thanks for that!
You are right, the maximum of the array isn't mentioned. The c=100 is also independent to the array size. It is needed to break at some point. Maybe it is better to mention that? What would you suggest?
e.g. The frog can make a maximum of 100 jumps. After that he is exhausted. 
But in the end ist is also the size of the array, bc every index can be used just one time. Otherwise we have a circle and with that the jumps are infinite.
And yes, if the frog is outside it doesn't matter if it is lower or greater than 100.

In that case, please clarify by adding (after "After that he is exhausted") "and cannot jump any more to leave the array."

Also please change "he" to "it" for consistency.

The last case should be split too. You need
* one more validator of long array but the frog can eventually jump out (maybe some of the jumps are >1 unit), and
* one more test of long array where the frog cannot jump out, even though some of the jumps are >1 unit, because it has jumped for 100 times already.
Also, I think the Fastest mode can be added.
Thx a lot for your help. I have adjusted it with your advices. Ready for a User acceptance test üòù
